Label.TEXT: HouseBot Sample Theme Introduction
If this Theme is running in a Software Remote, you can exit at any time by pressing the 'Exit Remote' Button.
This sample Theme will help illustrate many of the possibilities available for creating your own Themes.
What is a Theme?

A Theme defines a user interface that can be used by a Software Remote. Themes consist of one or more Panels (windows). The Panels are configured through a drag-and-drop style user interface that allows it to be customized for each users specific configuration.
Þ
View this Theme in:
• The HouseBot Theme Editor to examine how Theme Controls are configured.
• A Software Remote to see how the various Theme Controls function.
Getting Started
The navigation on this sample is setup to allow you to step through each Panel on a Software Remote to experiment with the various Theme Controls.
In a Software Remote, you can either click the 'Next' button in the corer of each Panel, or press the 'Index' button to jump to the Panel index.
In the Theme Editor, you can click the Panel tabs at the top of the screen to jump to the different Panels.
Sample Index
Today is:
Here is a static lable. It can contain any text and wrap to additional lines. Its transparent background makes it blend in with the Panel background.
These are Property Labels. They automatically reflect the state of ANY Property Value in HouseBot. These are mapped to display the System Time Properties.
Text and Labels
Ý
Ü
This Panel displays samples of static text labels and Property labels.
'Static Labels' can use any font or color.
They can have a set background color too.
They can use symbol fonts to display symbols. The arrows in this sample use the 'Symbol' font.
Or they can use a transparent background.
Static text and Property labels are used in Panels throughout this sample.
'Multi-State Buttons' can change appearance depending on the current Property Value. They can also change Properties differently depending on the current value.
'Property Change Buttons' can simply change a Property Value.
'Indicators' can display a different image depending on the current value of a Property.
Buttons and Indicators
This Panel uses samples of Button and Indicator controls.
These controls work with the 'Sample Theme Device' to simulate VCR Controls.
Ü
Ü
Ý
Other button controls can be used to:
• Execute Tasks
• Set a Mode state
Panel Change Buttons will jump to a new Panel (window).
ß
• Start an Application
Minimize Button
Þ
• Blank the Screen
• And more...
Button images are simply Windows Bitmap (BMP), Portable Network Graphics (PNG), or Jpeg (JPG) files. You can choose from HouseBot style buttons, or create your own.
Buttons and Indicators (continued)
This Panel uses more samples of Button and Indicator controls.
'Multi-State Buttons' can take on forms other than buttons. Here the control is used as a checkbox and radio buttons!
'Stop', 'Play', and 'Record' are actually transparent 'Multi-State' buttons. This allows you to click the text or the radio button!
Ü
This panel displays samples of Image controls.
This is a STATIC image. It does not change while the Software Remote is running.
The image below is a DYNAMIC image. It will automatically change when the associated Property Value that contains the image file name changes.
Press this button to change the image.
Þ
Images can be in Windows Bitmap (BMP), Portable Network Graphics (PNG), or Jpeg (JPG) format.
Other Controls
This panel displays samples Gauges, Sliders, and Edit controls.
Current Volume:
It can be changed with a Slider control.
Or change it by entering a value and pressing ENTER in the Edit control.
The controls below will all change the 'Volume' Property of the 'Sample Theme Device'.
Þ
Þ
The Gauge shows the current value graphically.
Or change it with a button.
Þ
Popup Panels
What are Panels?
Themes are constructed with two different types of Panels (windows).
• Primary Panels -
Will replace existing Panels and provide the main background window for the Software Remote.
Will popup over existing Primary (or other popup) Panels. Their position can be movable or fixed.
• Popup Panels -
The buttons below use Panel Change Button controls to call up various types of popup Panels.
You MUST Close each of the popup panels after pressing one of the style demonstrations above before viewing another style.
Panel Open Styles:
Panel with Transparent Areas
Rectangular areas can overlay applictions to reveal underlying buttons.
This Panel has transparent edges and holes. You can click right through the holes!
Popup 1
Popups provide more controls while still allowing access to the controls of the main Panel.
Popups can be moved by clicking on the background and dragging the Panel.
Popups can spawn other Popups too.
Once the Panel has been moved, it will remember its new position.
Or you can close this Poup when calling the next Popup.
Press to Close
Þ
Popup 2
You MUST Close this popup panel to continue.
Popup Types
Movable Attached Popup. Can be moved, but will also move with Primary Panel.
Movable Popup. Can be moved, and will NOT move with Primary Panel.
Fixed Attached Popup. Can NOT be moved, but will move with Primary Panel.
Fixed Popup. Can NOT be moved, and will NOT move with Primary Panel.
Press all of the samples buttons above to see how they all react at the same time!
This is another primary (background) Panel. To return to the previous primary Panel, press the 'Close' button.
Movable - Attached Popup
This panel can be moved anywhere on the screen by clicking on an open area of the window and dragging the panel.
Since it is 'Attached', it will move when the main panel is moved.
It will remember its last position and open in the same place the next time.
Movable - Popup
This panel can be moved anywhere on the screen by clicking on an open area of the window and dragging the panel.
It will remember its last position and open in the same place the next time.
Fixed - Popup
This panel can NOT be moved by clicking and dragging the panel.
Fixed Panels are set to open at specific coordinates.
Fixed - Attached
Since it is 'Attached', it will move when the main panel is moved.
This panel can NOT be moved by clicking and dragging the panel.
Fixed Panels are set to open at specific coordinates. This particular Panel is set to open in the center of the primary Panel.
Control Transparencies
This panel displays controls that have transparencies.
Image controls can be layered to create unique effects using partial tranparencies.
The two images on this Panel have semi-transparent areas which allow the background or the panel in the previous layer to show through.
Image controls are always displayed behind other controls. Multiple images can be layered on top of each other, if needed.
Other controls can also contain transparent (or semi-transparent) regions that allow the images or panel background to show through.
The example on this Panel shows two semi-transparent Button controls showing the images behind.
